PM11:15am

After a notably weak Q4 2017 performance, HSBC has delivered only a slightly
better start to Q1 2018. U/L PBT of $6,033m beat Company-compiled consensus
by just $31m (0.5%), but within this, a tiny charge of $0.2bn contributed a $0.4bn
(70%) impairment beat. Revenues of $13.85bn were a $0.1bn (0.7%) beat, offset
by a $0.5bn (6%) miss on costs. 1.9% QoQ loan growth and a 4bps QoQ NIM
expansion are welcome, but overall, slim pickings. HOLD.

trc Largely history now, I realise, but can somebody explain to me why the Daily Mail was so full of vitriol about Melrose during the GKN bid? Not usually an ally of Corbyn/Cable. Was it just some instant prejudice of Dacre's?
Dec69 - Skeptic Morning, not been to Bournemouth for years.
11:15 am
BE11:15am

Reporting season among banks does seem to have taken a pretty familiar shape ....

PM11:15am

Q1 2018 saw the usual seasonal bounce-back in EPS to 16c, (see Fig 1, page
2), albeit this represented a 3c (16%) consensus miss, primarily due to $0.9bn
of legal/conduct costs.
 By region, Hong Kong was, once again (and by a considerable margin) the
stand-out performer, contributing record u/l PBT of $3.15bn, some 52% of the
group u/l PBT (see Fig 2, page 2). This included a particularly strong
performance in Investment distribution, and improving deposit revenues.
 Within Global Banking and Markets, there was a mixed picture. An aggregate
2% YoY growth in revenues to $4.2bn contained particularly strong growth within
Global Liquidity and Cash Management (+17%), and Securities Services
(+12%), though FICC was notably weak (-16%).
 “Jaws” were modestly negative in the quarter, primarily reflecting $0.4bn
incremental investment spend in “growth and digital”, albeit HSBC’s commitment
to (modestly) positive jaws on a full-year basis is reaffirmed.
 HSBC has reinstated its share buyback one quarter earlier than expected, but
the amount (for the remainder of 2018) of $2bn is below consensual
expectations of c.$3bn; management sees more value in investment for growth.
 Customer loans grew by $18bn (1.9%) QoQ (see Fig 3, page 3), while NIM has
finally started to recover (see Fig 4, page 3), up 4bps QoQ to 1.67%.
 Hold rec and 740p target price reaffirmed. Forecasts under review, but as per
Fig 6, page 4, we do not expect HSBC to meet its 10% RoE target before 2021e.

BE11:19am

HSBC 1Q18 results overall are in-line with consensus
earnings expectation, but this was delivered via combination of a cost miss
($8.25bn u/l, +14% yoy and 6% worse than cons) and a beat on loan losses. The
revised 2018 cost guidance is about $1bn below current cons or c5% off underlying
profits, albeit much of this could be offset in 2018 forecasts by hard to forecast
lower loan losses. A lot of the questions on the 1Q18 earnings call were not
surprisingly about costs – and this will continue to be a focus into the Strategy Day
at or before 2Q18 results. Investing in the business, especially for a new CEO,
makes strategic sense albeit may lead to small near term cons EPS downgrades.

Mouselet Good morning capitalists
BE11:20am

Why Costs Are Growing: HSBC are funding increasing cost growth from the
higher revenues the bank is benefitting from in recent quarters and they will
continue to do so to capture growth opportunities, especially in HK/PRD region.
Specific drivers of cost growth called out in 1Q18 results include 1. PRD
expansion, including retail and wealth management, 2. China securities JV, (3)
digital and tech spend. We believe there is an element of ‘catch up’ with best in
class peers and new emerging competitors, especially on the digital spend. CFO
noted that ‘run-the-bank costs’ are down qoq while ‘change-the-bank costs’ are up.

BintmeisterGeneral @Sails Haha, I'm glad to hear it. Last time I visited the area I was surprised how much they've developed the beach front... it's looking a quite cool place to live now and Boscombe also looks to be benefiting.

BE11:21am

CFO Iain Mackay reiterated their
positive “jaws” guidance for 2018 and when questioned said “around 1% mark”. We
believe that the jaws guidance is narrowing from 1.0-1.5ppt in the prior quarter and
expectations of low-to-mid single jaws earlier in 2017 (albeit that may have reflected
sell side optimism rather than company guidance). HSBC are also guiding
underlying FY18 costs to be broadly similar to 1Q18 annualised which we believe
will be a challenge given the normal seasonal drift upwards in costs intra-year. A
material weakening in GBP, given the concentration of HQ and GBM higher earners
based in London, may help with delivering the positive jaws target – otherwise this
looks like a challenging target for 2018.

At one point, the share price fell so low that Beijing-based ICBC, the largest bank in the world, drew up a proposal, seen by one senior HSBC staffer in China, to take over HSBC. That proposal never made its way to the HSBC board.

“Today, to acquire us would require a very large cheque,” says Mr Flint. “That is highly unlikely.”

BE11:34am

We now forecast for EPS to fall from 41p this year to 32p in
2019e and 35p in 2020e, below what we believe the market anticipates.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

But let me spin to the bid stuff, because that's where all eyes are currently.

BE11:35am

Prior to the recent rally in the share price the attractiveness of VM to any bidder was
clear in our mind. The ability to potentially acquire a business at or even below its book
value with a likely earnings stream of over 10% RoTE before any possible integration
benefits is an appealing proposition.
But trading back at book value and before any premium means that the strategic
rational needs to be clear. To our mind it is not. The Virgin Brand itself has value and it
is not clear that integrating VM within another business is an obvious move. Any
acquirer would also be required to continue to pay the 1% revenue fee to Virgin Group
for the use of the Virgin Brand, another reason to keep Virgin Money separate. The
recent experience of TSB, acquired by Sabadell in 2015, in integrating customers on a
new banking platform is another reminder of the challenges of such operations, even if
the current platform for VM is almost certainly a lot cleaner as a starting point.

ESM Anyone got an idea what s up in Berkeley today?
BE11:36am

So talk in the market about a plausible valuation in the mid 400s for Virgin looks a bit overcooked, going by Exane's argument.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

That said we consider 370p to be a realistic price in such a scenario. While ascribing
such a price is complicated given the uncertainty as to the level of bid spec in the
current price and a volatile EPS outlook, this would represent a similar change in P/E
multiple to what was paid for Aldermore. The price for ALD was close to 40% above its
pre bid spec average 1 month price. Using an average 2018-20e EPS and levering up
VM’s pre bid spec P/E multiple by a similar amount would point to a P/E of just over
10x and imply 370p.

BE11:48am

Here's Barclays to say "calm down"

BE11:48am

The highlights are 1) a tough comp in South African textbooks driving the Growth division to be down 12% organic; 2) lower returns helping North America Higher Education courseware to grow “slightly”; 3) the rest of North America showing decent growth (to get the division to +3%) but there are positive timing affects in K-12 assessment and 4) all guidance is reiterated.

We have not published forecasts for 1Q18 and there is no consensus. This is because Q1 numbers for Pearson are often volatile as, for some parts of the group, it is a small quarter. This is shown in the numbers where Core’s 6% organic growth is boosted by timing benefits and Growth’s -12% organic growth is impacted by a very tough comp in South African school textbooks.

Clearly the market will attempt to derive meaning from these organic growth numbers but in truth there are always some apparently surprising variations in Q1 and these have not tended to be useful indicators for the full year. We think that the only true conclusion here is that there are no new material underlying positives or negatives for the business and guidance is reiterated.

Baupost, the Boston-based hedge fund run by Seth Klarman, the cult value investor, took up a position late last year in Dixons Carphone, Britain’s largest electrical retail chain. While many large investors buy and sell shares on a daily basis, Baupost’s investments draw attention because it is highly selective, and Mr Klarman buys only when he believes something is so cheap it provides a handsome “margin of safety”.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

New management team likely to speed up decision making and improve the customer offer. New CEO Alex Baldock (ex Shop Direct) has recently started and has put in place a new senior executive team designed to speed up decision making in the business, cut out unnecessary layers of management and improve the customer offer for instance by improving data analytics and mobile conversion.

BE12:01pm

Post Brexit currency headwinds have subsided. Dixons Carphone has suffered from manufacturers raising prices aggressively post the sterling devaluation in 2016. However, this has now annualised and we are seeing more competitive prices coming through in areas like laptops and iPads, which should be helpful for volumes.

BE12:01pm

Audio-visual market likely to be strong short term, white goods market challenging but less volatile. In common with previous cycles, we expect TV demand to be boosted and brought forward prior to the World Cup in June, helped also by new models and more competitive pricing. The white goods market (around a third of sales) is likely to remain subdued owing to housing weakness, although tends to be less volatile, being driven mainly by replacement demand.

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

Mobile trends tough but not getting worse – although recent volumes are likely to have been boosted by new product launches eg the iPhone X and Samsung Galaxy S9, we expect the Mobile market to remain challenging given affordability issues and a lack of incremental innovation. Once DC has more visibility over network renegotiations later this year we expect a more aggressive cost cutting programme to de-risk the business and also to make it less working capital intensive.

PM12:06pm

FTSE 100 wins in late-cycle and Style Cycle 'Slowdown'

The FTSE 100 has very little to do with the strength of the UK economy given its c70% revenue exposure outside the UK - readily apparent in the immediate aftermath of the Brexit vote. UK large caps should instead be viewed as a barbell trade of Energy plus Quality stocks. The former are supported by improving global late-cycle indicators (e.g. rising capacity utilization and capex intentions) while the latter benefit from 'Slowdown' in leading indicators highlighted in Style Cycle report. Among major equity indices, the SMI and FTSE 100 continue to be most-preferred in this late-cycle 'Slowdown' phase.

Sterling pressured by rate divergence; favours FTSE 100

Sterling is likely to weaken on slowing global leading indicators, lower forecasted inflation in the UK relative to the US over the coming year (Chart 8), and policy rate divergence. Our economists expect the Fed to hike six times over 2018-19, but the BoE to only hike twice over the same period amid disappointing GDP growth and falling inflation. For global investors, this favours the FTSE 100 on a currency-hedged basis.

GBKrona thanks @BE
PM12:06pm

Valuation and Sentiment = attractive entry point

FTSE 100 has a DY premium and Book-to-Price ratio versus global peers near their highest levels in two decades. Moreover, our Technical Strategist shows FTSE-100 is at a 17-year bullish breakout. UK equity funds have seen large cumulative outflows over the past two years (vs. inflows globally) and UK is a big consensus underweight in FMS. That may be turning -allocations rose in April from an all-time low reading in the March.

UK can be a place to diversify from crowded sectors

Our Global Quant team shows institutional investors are overweight Discretionary and Tech, and underweight Energy. UK stocks offer a relatively cheap way to diversify away from crowded sectors (Charts 3 and 4). Our UK Beat Factor screen showcases BofAML's most out-of-consensus longs. These include GVC, Stanchart, National Grid, RSA, Ashtead - see Table 3 for the full list.
